node.title: Error for C code in Moose

node.bodyText:
addParam needs a type: ie.
params.addParam<FunctionName>("function", "Function describing energy release rate type parameter distribution");
Also no semicolon is needed after the constructor
_function_prop(isParamValid("function") ? &getFunction("function") : NULL)

Same goes for your gc param. Perhaps params.addParam<Real>?
Also I think when you declare the property, that is going to need a type: declareProperty<Real>

Thanks  Jessecarter. I will try it and i will let you know what happens.
Kind regards,
Toan

Thanks  Jessecarter.  it is working.
Thank for your help.
Kind regards,
Toan

node.title: LineValueSampler
node.bodyText:
Hello,
When I use the LineValueSampler in the s5 from phase_field/tutorials/spinodal_decomposition.
It shows that:
Task add_postprocessor is not registered to build VectorPostprocessor derived objects
I s there any problem in my change?
[Postprocessors]
  [./c_end]
    type =  LineValueSampler
    start_point = '0 0 0'
    end_point = '25 0 0'
    variable = c
    num_points = 26
    sort_by =  id
    execute_on = timestep_end
  [../]
[]

It’s a VectorPostprocessor, not a Postprocessor.
Use a [VectorPostprocessors] block instead.

node.title: compile PETSc on cluster
node.bodyText:
Hi, dear all,
I am always stacked when compiling PETSc using the code ./scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh on cluster, as shown in the attached picture. I don't know how to fix it, I am following the steps on
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/hpc_install_moose.html
Thanks,
Shizhe
What you are seeing is what you should be seeing. There is no error here.

Maybe "stacked" means "stuck" here, and the hypre download is not completing. This is odd, because the PETSc config script appears to have successfully downloaded SUPERLU from github already. Try giving it more time.

I received notification emails that you posted (twice) to this discussion, but I am not seeing those posts. From what I am reading (in my email I did receive from GitHub), it would seem PETSc may not have successfully finished building. Can you post the configure.log for PETSc as well? That should reside at:
moose/petsc/configure.log

Thanks!
Thank you all. I have solved this problem, it seems I had trouble git hypre, I downloaded it manually and modified the configure code, it works.

node.title: Can MOOSE users easily use SEACAS?
node.bodyText:
libmesh is a submodule of MOOSE, and i see libmesh uses a lot of the libraries that SEACAS, https://github.com/gsjaardema/seacas , uses.    I don't know, but perhaps the entire SEACAS is hiding somewhere in libmesh.
I tried, and failed, to get SEACAS working on my computer - you have to get netcdf, hdf, and various other things, and i just ran out of time.
Does anyone have tips for using libmesh's already-built libraries to quickly get a working copy of SEACAS ?    (Or, you could suggest a well-documented alternative for writing exodus files using python.  The VTK libraries are almost perfect in this regard, but their exodusII writer has some bugs, boohoo.)

I am not sure how helpful this will be... But this is how I was building/including SEACAS tools into the old moose-environment package: https://github.com/idaholab/package_builder/blob/master/build_from_source/template/seacas-tools
The scripts therein might help you design your own installing method.
Thanks @milljm

Hey Andy, I had problems building SEACAS as well when using em2ex, especially on the Travis CI machines that I use for testing, so I wrote a pyexodus class that I use to write to an exodus file after converting from a Petrel file. It's in here: https://github.com/cpgr/em2ex/tree/master/pyexodus
It's pretty straightforward, and basically mimics the Exodus python API without needing SEACAS.
All it needs is the python netCDF4 which is easy to install
Thanks @cpgr .  Do you know if libmesh already has netCDF4 ?

I rely on the python one that is trivial to install pip instal netCDF4
I've also used meshio as @GregVernon mentioned and it is excellent, but didn't fit my particular use case (conversion from geological model).

@WilkAndy Here are several options for creating Exodus files via Python, depending on what your use-case is
Translation from another format
There's a fantastic Python module called meshio (available on PyPi) that can read, write, and convert between the following mesh formats:


Abaqus
ANSYS msh
AVS-UCD
CGNS
DOLFIN XML
Exodus
FLAC3D
H5M
Kratos/MDPA
Medit
MED/Salome
Nastran (bulk data)
Neuroglancer precomputed format
Gmsh (format versions 2.2, 4.0, and 4.1)
OBJ
OFF
PERMAS
PLY
STL
Tecplot .dat
TetGen .node/.ele
SVG (2D only, output only)
SU2
UGRID
VTK
VTU
WKT (TIN)
XDMF


Automated mesh-generation and export to Exodus
You could use Coreform Cubit, which has a Python-API that is also accessible as an importable Python module. and natively exports Exodus files.  I've automated many meshing routines (DoE, optimization, etc) using this technique in my former career as an FEA analyst, and as a student.  You can get a free edition of Coreform Cubit, called Coreform Cubit Learn, by following the instructions on this page.  The only limitations of the free edition are personal non-commercial use, educational use, and an export limitation of 50k elements.
SEACAS
As noted by @cpgr, SEACAS includes a python module, exodus.py for directly querying or modifying Exodus files.  There are also some conversion tools that you might find helpful:

exo2mat and mat2exo  -- convert Exodus to / from Matlab file format
exotxt and txtexo -- convert Exodus to / from an equivalent ASCII format (which is documented somewhere)
Excellent, thanks @GregVernon

node.title: postprocessor ordering
node.bodyText:
Not sure if this is an "issue" or not, but I recently came across a case my postprocessor results were dependent on the order they were listed in the input file. I have several that were used together in a ParsedFunction, which gets output with a Postprocessor, and then that result made it into another ParsedFunction, whose output was also produced with a Postprocessor. If I had that second Postprocessor listed above the first in the input file, the results came out lagged by a timestep even if I told the processors to execute more often (ie. linear). Not a big deal (easy to fix), but I just thought I'd inquire if this was something expected.
I was able to reproduce with this minimal input file:
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 2
  xmin = 0
  xmax = 1
  ymin = 0
  ymax = 1
  nx = 2
  ny = 2
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [./v]
  [../]
[]

[Variables]
  [./u]
  [../]
[]

[Functions]
  [./constant_func]
    type = ConstantFunction
    value = 2.798
  [../]
  [./test]
    type = ParsedFunction
    vars = 'value1 value2'
    vals = 'value1 value2'
    value = 'value1+value2'
  [../]
  [./test2]
    type = ParsedFunction
    vars = 'test'
    vals = 'test'
    value = 'test'
  [../]
[]


[ICs]
  [./u_ic]
    type = ConstantIC
    variable = u
    value = 2
  [../]
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [./one]
    type = ConstantAux
    variable = v
    value = 1
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  [../]
[]

[Kernels]
  [./diff]
    type = Diffusion
    variable = u
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
  [./left]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = u
    boundary = left
    value = 0
  [../]
  [./right]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = u
    boundary = right
    value = 1
  [../]
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [./value1]
    type = FunctionValuePostprocessor
    function = constant_func
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  [../]
  [./value2]
    type = FunctionValuePostprocessor
    function = 2*t
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  [../]

  # these next two postprocessors should output the same result
  # but will not if 'test2' is listed before 'test'
  [./test2]
    type = FunctionValuePostprocessor
    function = 'test2'
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  [../]
  [./test]
    type = FunctionValuePostprocessor
    function = 'test'
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  num_steps = 5
[]

[Outputs]
  csv = true
[]

[Problem]
  solve = false
[]

Dependency resolution of postprocessors is not carried through indirect dependencies that result from the use of postprocessors in parsed functions with said function values then being used in another postprocessor.
postprocessor1 -> function -> postprocessor2

The dependency resolution only recognizes
postprocessor1 -> postprocessor2

A quick workaround would be to allow users to explicitly specify indirect dependencies. The better solution, a complete overhaul of the dependency system, is being researched as a funded project as far as I know.
Like so: fa926be
Great! The input file I posted above might make a good test for this.
PR at #16358 (I used a simpler test based on the current time)
Is there not some kind of parsed postprocessor @dschwen ? I'm only using Functions to combine postprocessor results. If I could get rid of the Functions then maybe I could get dependency resolution.
ping @dschwen
How are you combining them? Difference, sum, average... ?
All of the above.
I don't think the code duplication resulting from a parsed postprocessor is acceptable. I'm working on a quick fix now.

You may consider creating a custom object to compute what you need, perhaps the new Reporter system is worth a look.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Reporters/index.html

node.title: For PFF model, what is different by using the grain tracker and by not using  grain tracker
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose
I am simulating the PFF example. I used a input file with including the grain tracker part and without including the grain tracker part to run program for the same micro structure . I received two different results for crack propagating.
Could you please let me know  what is different by using the grain tracker and by not using the grain tracker in Moose for PFF model?
Kind regards,
Toan
It will be helpful if you attach your input file. What do you use grain tracker for?

Thanks Jiang
Right now, I understand what is different because i used two constitutive function different


without grain tracker
[./elasticity_tensor]
type = ComputeElasticityTensorCP
C_ijkl = '1.27e5 0.708e5 0.708e5 1.27e5 0.708e5 1.27e5 0.7355e5 0.7355e5 0.7355e5'
fill_method = symmetric9
read_prop_user_object = prop_read
[../]


with grain tracker


[./ElasticityTensor]
type = ComputePolycrystalElasticityTensor
grain_tracker = grain_tracker
outputs = all
[../]
Kind regards,
Toan

node.title: Permission denied in git status command
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am a new user in Moose code and moving forward step by step by asking questions in this forum. Thank you so much all!
I am working on tutorial01. I was able to run a new input file and see the output through peacock. It took a week for me to get this stage. However, unfortunately, I have some issue to run "git status" It shows:
(moose) hyeom@ERB914-7920:~/projects/babbler$ git status
fatal: .git/index: index file open failed: Permission denied

In GitHub desktop, it says "last fetched just now on" but I cannot Pull in Git tab in Atom. I think I messed it up somehow. Can you please provide some clues to resolve this? Thanks. Sung

Permission denied errors usually are the result of running commands with sudo.
Can you perform a long listing while 'babbler'?
ls -latrh ~/projects/babbler
Thanks!

Dear Jason,
I typed the command and the result is shown below. Can you see some issue? Thanks. Sung.
(moose) hyeom@ERB914-7920:~/projects/babbler$ ls -latrh ~/projects/babbler
total 476K
-rw-r--r-- 1 hyeom hyeom  26K Nov 24 12:17 LICENSE
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 24 12:17 include
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 24 12:17 scripts
-rw-r--r-- 1 hyeom hyeom  183 Nov 24 12:17 README.md
-rw-r--r-- 1 hyeom hyeom 2.1K Nov 24 12:17 Makefile
-rwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom  470 Nov 24 12:17 run_tests
-rw-r--r-- 1 hyeom hyeom   86 Nov 24 12:17 testroot
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 24 12:17 unit
-rw-r--r-- 1 hyeom hyeom  738 Nov 24 12:17 .clang-format
-rw-r--r-- 1 hyeom hyeom 3.2K Nov 24 12:17 .gitignore
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 24 12:25 build
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 24 12:26 test
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 24 12:26 .libs
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 27 11:51 ..
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 28 15:06 src
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 28 15:07 lib
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 28 15:08 .
-rwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 426K Nov 28 15:08 babbler-opt
-rw-r--r-- 1 hyeom hyeom 7.7K Nov 28 15:09 .previous_test_results.json
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 30 09:53 doc
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 30 09:53 .git
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 30 11:18 problems
Better do a ls -latrh ~/projects/babbler/.git

As Jason stated, you've probably run git with sudo at some point, changing the ownership of some internal git files to root. You can fix that by doing
sudo chown -R hyeom:hyeom ~/projects/babbler

and then never use sudo again when working with MOOSE :-)

maybe there are aspects of git which are not owned by you... can you perform the following:
ls -latrh ~/projects/babler/.git/
Thanks!
EDIT: woops. Didn't see that Daniel already replied.

Dear Daniel,
It showed the below after typing ls -latrch ~/projects/babber/.git
(moose) hyeom@ERB914-7920:~/projects/babbler$ ls -latrh ~/projects/babbler/.git
total 4.0K
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 24 12:17 branches
-rw-r--r-- 1 hyeom hyeom   73 Nov 24 12:17 description
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 24 12:17 hooks
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 24 12:17 info
-rw-r--r-- 1 hyeom hyeom   23 Nov 24 12:17 HEAD
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 24 12:23 logs
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 24 12:25 refs
---------- 1 hyeom hyeom   41 Nov 28 14:32 ORIG_HEAD
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 28 14:37 objects
---------- 1 hyeom hyeom 2.7K Nov 28 14:37 index
---------- 1 hyeom hyeom   15 Nov 28 14:37 COMMIT_EDITMSG
-rw-r--r-- 1 hyeom hyeom  262 Nov 28 15:02 config
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 28 15:08 ..
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 30 09:53 .
---------- 1 hyeom hyeom    0 Nov 30 11:29 FETCH_HEAD
After then, I tried the sudo chown and then typed git status. However, it still says "fatal: .git/index: index file open failed: Permission denied"
Sung

Daniel and Jason,
As you said, I think some of the files (please see above) are not owned by me. Can you please let me know how to change the ownership?
Sincerely,
Sung

Hi Sung
Type: chmod +rw file_name (or * to get them all at once), in the .git directory, to change file read/write priviledges.
Best,
Guillaume

Guillaume,
Thanks. Now I can run "git status" after changing the ownership of .git folder. After then I typed "git add problems" and it showed another error. There are many permission issues... Sung
(moose) hyeom@ERB914-7920:~/projects/babbler$ git add problems
error: insufficient permission for adding an object to repository database .git/objects
error: problems/pressure_diffusion.i: failed to insert into database
error: unable to index file 'problems/pressure_diffusion.i'
fatal: updating files failed

Maybe try changing the permissions recursively, for all files in the folder at once.
So 'chmod +rw --recursive ~/projects/babbler'

Guillaume,
Thanks. I run it but it showed many "cannot access" error messages.
(moose) hyeom@ERB914-7920:~/projects/babbler$ chmod +rw --recursive ~/projects/babbler
chmod: cannot access '/home/hyeom/projects/babbler/.git/objects/01/6580497728634160a6541a6342e2ba07000696': Permission denied
chmod: cannot access '/home/hyeom/projects/babbler/.git/objects/02/ae105e1a8d4370e00d1ce6bba5a072e299ad19': Permission denied
chmod: cannot access '/home/hyeom/projects/babbler/.git/objects/03/f7cb153298d959ee5bbc4493ad80c87341a684': Permission denied
chmod: cannot access '/home/hyeom/projects/babbler/.git/objects/0b/3f587194e53ab2c855ea66dac23662289fec90': Permission denied
chmod: cannot access '/home/hyeom/projects/babbler/.git/objects/17/b27300a29aad760be364281469b72f0ff4d1d7': Permission denied
chmod: cannot access '/home/hyeom/projects/babbler/.git/objects/34/154808f950bd18324a8b5ed914fc737c4dd931': Permission denied
chmod: cannot access '/home/hyeom/projects/babbler/.git/objects/34/58c0efe9c0fe75be67df29bac8601f8a28c927': Permission denied
chmod: cannot access '/home/hyeom/projects/babbler/.git/objects/3a/13df19eef2cc5b3df81d920175b31c411ca88c': Permission denied
chmod: cannot access '/home/hyeom/projects/babbler/.git/objects/3d/ffbd86b56f30d464d543ac4542443a1fc0a04e': Permission denied
chmod: cannot access '/home/hyeom/projects/babbler/.git/objects/47/d8ee3d8a753c186f5aed84296b42661f9e3028': Permission denied
chmod: cannot access '/home/hyeom/projects/babbler/.git/objects/62/c62ed143f8a6868635ac82eef6a66791957e03': Permission denied
chmod: cannot access '/home/hyeom/projects/babbler/.git/objects/79/201b6137aa03fe34b8c5867044a2f187fb6eea': Permission denied
chmod: cannot access '/home/hyeom/projects/babbler/.git/objects/87/249798ab181373d276a068dd3aec85d6d8ac4d': Permission denied
chmod: cannot access '/home/hyeom/projects/babbler/.git/objects/8c/aaf328a9718c6057e7f587a824f05af242d2e2': Permission denied
chmod: cannot access '/home/hyeom/projects/babbler/.git/objects/96/027c6336b3aecb7b9eea2a09a81f5df08e3efb': Permission denied
chmod: cannot access '/home/hyeom/projects/babbler/.git/objects/a3/2d71723da2ea0f4273943acd5192fbe1a717c0': Permission denied
chmod: cannot access '/home/hyeom/projects/babbler/.git/objects/b5/52b8e3d4fc5f233a5c9e8bf0d8e9bb400ed992': Permission denied
chmod: cannot access '/home/hyeom/projects/babbler/.git/objects/b5/6d12faeae50810d231b12b1f6b7b37cf9b0d0e': Permission denied
chmod: cannot access '/home/hyeom/projects/babbler/.git/objects/e1/8a5a2ec524dee700af30333b153710d391f471': Permission denied

Guillaume,
I am frustrated... I tried two things again.
1)
(moose) hyeom@ERB914-7920:~/projects/babbler$ sudo chown -R hyeom:hyeom /projects/babbler
[sudo] password for hyeom:
2)
(moose) hyeom@ERB914-7920:/projects/babbler$ sudo chmod +rw --recursive /projects/babbler
3)
(moose) hyeom@ERB914-7920:/projects/babbler$ git add problems
error: insufficient permission for adding an object to repository database .git/objects
error: problems/pressure_diffusion.i: failed to insert into database
error: unable to index file 'problems/pressure_diffusion.i'
fatal: updating files failed
It still showed the error message. It is not easy.

Guillaume,
Interestingly, now the git status doesn't work again. I am sorry for taking your time on this issue.
(moose) hyeom@ERB914-7920:~/projects/babbler$ git status
fatal: failed to read object b56d12faeae50810d231b12b1f6b7b37cf9b0d0e: Permission denied

The two commands you ran (chown -R ... and chmod --recursive ...) do similar things. -R is a short hand for --recursive.
The first one gives you ownership of the files, and the second read/write access
Can you check the permissions again? With ls -latrh. Maybe run that in ~/projects/babbler and ~/projects/babbler/.git

If fixing the permissions is becoming too time consuming, I recommend you re-create the application, and only move the files that you modified to the new application.
If this is your first commit, it should not take too long.

Guillaume,
Please see the two ls -latrh commands. Can you see something strange?
1)
(moose) hyeom@ERB914-7920:~/projects/babbler$ ls -latrh /projects/babbler
total 476K
-rw-r--r-- 1 hyeom hyeom  26K Nov 24 12:17 LICENSE

-rwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 426K Nov 28 15:08 babbler-opt
-rw-r--r-- 1 hyeom hyeom 7.7K Nov 28 15:09 .previous_test_results.json
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 30 09:53 doc
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 30 11:18 problems
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Dec  1 11:29 .git
2)
(moose) hyeom@ERB914-7920:/projects/babbler$ ls -latrh ~/projects/babbler/.git
total 8.0K
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 24 12:17 branches
-rw-r--r-- 1 hyeom hyeom   73 Nov 24 12:17 description
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 24 12:17 hooks
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 24 12:17 info
-rw-r--r-- 1 hyeom hyeom   23 Nov 24 12:17 HEAD
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 24 12:23 logs
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 24 12:25 refs
-rw-r--r-- 1 hyeom hyeom   41 Nov 28 14:32 ORIG_HEAD
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 28 14:37 objects
-rw-r--r-- 1 hyeom hyeom  262 Nov 28 15:02 config
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Nov 28 15:08 ..
-rw-r--r-- 1 hyeom hyeom    0 Nov 30 11:29 FETCH_HEAD
-rw-r--r-- 1 hyeom hyeom 2.7K Dec  1 10:26 index
-rw-r--r-- 1 hyeom hyeom 1.4K Dec  1 10:39 COMMIT_EDITMSG
drwxr-xr-x 1 hyeom hyeom 4.0K Dec  1 11:29 .

I agree. I may remove the whole babbler directory (should I do that in github website?) and restart the tutorial again.
Sincerely,
Sung

The permissions look fine. You are the owner of the files (thanks to chown) and you have read/write access on all these files (first set of rw- is for the owner).
You can worry about removing the directory later (from both your github account and your computer). For now, maybe try restarting the tutorial without using sudo.

Guillaume,
Thanks. I will restart the tutorial with a new directory (e.g., babbler2) and see what happens.
Sincerely,
Sung

node.title: moose on hpc cluster
node.bodyText:
Hi Everyone,
I am trying to install moose on psc cluster following this instruction:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/hpc_install_moose.html
I have completed petsc and libmesh compilations, but when I do make in test folder I get errors complaining about finding petsc:

Do you have any suggestion?
Thanks a lot,
Roozbeh

Assuming you have compiled PETSc properly. Can you check the configure log of libMesh carefully to see if it detected PETSc? You may compiled libMesh without PETSc. If that is the case, you may try telling libMesh configure where and which PETSc to use with something like PETSC_DIR=[you petsc directory here] PETSC_ARCH=[the petsc build, could be something like arch-moose] ./scripts/update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh.
Thanks Yaqi. There was a mistake on my side, there were some old compilation files left, which caused the problem. I redid everything based on the instruction page, and it works well.

node.title: Finite strain rotations

node.bodyText: Since @recuero has been working on this recently, he might be able to give more details.

@tophmatthews My two cents below. I do not know much about the history of these classes though...

Can I get away from the rotations if I am only dealing with things growing or shrinking, and not rotating?

Maybe. I believe you are suggesting mixing small and large strain kinematic descriptions, i.e. the rotation matrix being unity. This solution would require having prior knowledge that the system does not rotate in any part of it (not just rigid body rotations), which may happen in very particular cases.

Alright, makes sense using the ADRadialReturnStressUpdate technique since I typically use an evolving elasticity tensor, but won't this lead to a mismatch in stress calculations when perform_finite_strain_rotations=false?

Doesn't ADRadialReturnStressUpdate override the calculation of stresses in ADComputeMultipleInelasticStress? I think I don't understand.

when should I not do perform_finite_strain_rotations=false

I would choose perform_finite_strain_rotations=true any time you have large deformation kinematics. Those transformations appear necessary for that application. True, AD tensor operations are a significant drag, but choosing, in general, to disregard rotations for large deformations seems like could lead to erroneous results.
Others can chime in with more accurate explanations.

I agree with @recuero. For any finite strain kinematics rotations have to be done to get the correct cauchy stress in the deformed configuration. That being said if your material is already doing the rotations to get the correct cauchy stress then you can set it to false. For example I have a radial return material that performs this rotation internally because I have a different way of computing the stress in the configuration.
In short with vanilla moose and all the radial return methods already implemented in tensor mechanics, this should be set to true if you're doing finite strain calculations.
Cheers
Srinath
So perhaps it's my ignorance about what "rotation" means. My mesh is a 2DRz cylinder. Is rotation of the mesh rotating (not really possible), or can it include large deformation?

@tophmatthews i think the rotations here come from the polar decomposition of the deformation gradient and are not the same as a rigid body rotation. Rigid body rotations i believe have to handled independently. Any other mechanics experts, please correct me if I am wrong

Yeah, so rigid body rotations happen if F = RU, for U = identity (other issues such as correct BCs would come into play here for most of our static simulations). In general, R (rotation matrix) is needed to capture the local change of orientation. So, it's not so much a mesh rotating, but the result of applying locally (integration point wise) the polar decomposition. You could have drastic changes of orientation without rigid body modes.

Here is a decent example of why we need to do rotations when using the cauchy stress, this is from abaqus theory manual. Note moose uses a variant of the Hughes widget algorithm for computing the strains (Rashid 1993) i think
https://classes.engineering.wustl.edu/2009/spring/mase5513/abaqus/docs/v6.6/books/stm/default.htm?startat=ch03s02ath60.html
Okay great, so I need them. I also misread the code, and indeed the stress calculations are consistent due to _is_elasticity_tensor_guaranteed_isotropic being true.

@WilkAndy and I discussed this issue in detail a few years back on one of his pull requests (I think on one of the Cosserat PRs), but I haven't been able to find that PR and discussion yet. Once I do I'll post a link here for completeness.
Hi @sapitts .  It might have been #9438 .   It's fun to read these old discussions.  Anyway, i concur with what's been written above

node.title: _console and MPI rank!=0 output
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
I have an object derived from Output (and UserObjectInterface, if that makes any difference), that writes stuff to _console.  Everything works as planned for the MPI rank=0 processor.  However, i believe the rank!=0 processors' _console stream does not get sent to std::out.   How do i instruct the rank!=0 _console to be written to std::out ?
Note - it's quite late at night (for me) so i could be completely wrong about this rank!=0 stuff - perhaps there's another bug in my code.  So don't spend too long thinking about this if it doesn't make sense to you!
a

OK, i just found the answer:
my_app-opt -i input.i --keep-cout
and my notes demonstrate that i must have asked this before, duh
I'm going to start asking a bunch of questions I know the answer to in order to climb the Most Answers leaderboard 😄 Just kidding, you nailed it!
Just stay up way past your bedtime....
